attributes.text:
Wraps a set of elements and offers a whole set of features to query or modify them.

Chaining

The collection uses an interesting concept called a “Builder” to make its code short and simple. The Builder pattern is an object-oriented programming design pattern that has been gaining popularity.

In a nutshell: Every method on the collection returns the collection object itself, allowing you to ‘chain’ upon it, for example:

qx.bom.Collection.query("a").addClass("test")
  .setStyle("visibility", "visible").setAttribute("html", "foo");

Content Manipulation

Most methods that accept “content” will accept one or more arguments of any of the following:

  • A DOM node element
  • An array of DOM node elements
  • A collection
  • A string representing HTML

Example:

qx.bom.Collection.query("#div1").append(
  document.createElement("br"),
  qx.bom.Collection.query("#div2"),
  "after div2"
);

Content inserting methods ({@link #append}, {@link #prepend}, {@link #before}, {@link #after}, and {@link #replaceWith}) behave differently depending on the number of DOM elements currently selected by the collection. If there is only one element in the collection, the content is inserted to that element; content that was in another location in the DOM tree will be moved by this operation. This is essentially the same as the W3C DOM appendChild method.

When multiple elements are selected by a collection, these methods clone the content before inserting it to each element. Since the content can only exist in one location in the document tree, cloning is required in these cases so that the same content can be used in multiple locations.

This rule also applies to the selector-insertion methods ({@link #appendTo}, {@link #prependTo}, {@link #insertBefore}, {@link #insertAfter}, and {@link #replaceAll}), but the auto-cloning occurs if there is more than one element selected by the Selector provided as an argument to the method.

When a specific behavior is needed regardless of the number of elements selected, use the {@link #clone} or {@link #remove} methods in conjunction with a selector-insertion method. This example will always clone #Thing, append it to each element with class OneOrMore, and leave the original #Thing unmolested in the document:

qx.bom.Collection.query("#Thing").clone().appendTo(".OneOrMore");

This example will always remove #Thing from the document and append it to .OneOrMore:

qx.bom.Collection.query("#Thing").remove().appendTo(".OneOrMore");
Support HTML elements, HTML strings and selector strings

Where to start looking for the expression or any element in the document which refers to a valid document to create new elements (useful when dealing with HTML->Element translation in multi document environments).
Processes the input and translates it to a collection instance.
Newly created collection
String containing one or multiple elements or pure text content
Context in which newly DOM elements are created from the markup
Converts a HTML string into a collection
Collection containing the create DOM elements
Identifier for DOM element to found

Queries the DOM for an element matching the given ID. Must not contain the ”#” like when using the query engine.

This is mainly a wrapper for document.getElementById and returns a collection for easy querying and modification instead of the pure DOM node.
Found element wrapped into Collection
CSS Selector String
Context element to filter start search in
Queries the selector engine and returns a new collection for convenient modfication and quering.
Collection instance to wrap found elements
Relative DOM element (iteration point in selector processing)
Child to insert
Callback for {@link #after} to apply the insertion of content
Relative DOM element (iteration point in selector processing)
Child to insert
Callback for {@link #append} to apply the insertion of content
Relative DOM element (iteration point in selector processing)
Child to insert
Callback for {@link #before} to apply the insertion of content
Outer DOM element
Finds the deepest child inside the given element
Inner DOM element
Method name to execute
Optional selector to filter the result
Internal helper to work with hierarchy result arrays.
Collection from all found elements
Array of DOM elements or HTML strings
Method to execute for each fragment/element created
Helper method for all DOM manipulation methods which deal with set of elements or HTML fragments.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
All arguments (selectors) of the original method call
Name of the original method to wrap
Helper for wrapping the methods to insert/replace content so that they can be used in reverse order (selector is given to the target method instead)
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Relative DOM element (iteration point in selector processing)
Child to insert
Callback for {@link #prepend} to apply the insertion of content
Array to transform into new collection
Extend the chaining with a new collection, while storing the previous collection to make it accessible via end().
The newly created collection
Valid selector (CSS3 + extensions)
Context element (result elements must be children of this element)
Adds more elements, matched by the given expression, to the set of matched elements.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
The class name to add
Adds a className to the given element If successfully added the given className will be returned
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
A reference to an DOM element or a HTML string

Insert content after each of the matched elements.

Supports lists of DOM elements or HTML strings through a variable argument list.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Add the previous selection to the current selection.
Newly build collection containing the current and and the previous collection.
A reference to an DOM element or a HTML string

Append content to the inside of every matched element.

Supports lists of DOM elements or HTML strings through a variable argument list.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
List of selector expressions

Append all of the matched elements to another, specified, set of elements.

This operation is, essentially, the reverse of doing a regular qx.bom.Collection.query(A).append(B), in that instead of appending B to A, you’re appending A to B.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
A reference to an DOM element or a HTML string

Insert content before each of the matched elements.

Supports lists of DOM elements or HTML strings through a variable argument list.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Optional selector to match

Get a set of elements containing all of the unique immediate children of each of the matched set of elements.

This set can be filtered with an optional expression that will cause only elements matching the selector to be collected.

Also note: while parents() will look at all ancestors, children() will only consider immediate child elements.
The new collection
Whether events should be copied as well
Clone all DOM elements of the collection and return them in a newly created collection.
The copied elements
Expression to filter the elements with

Get a set of elements containing the closest parent element that matches the specified selector, the starting element included.

Closest works by first looking at the current element to see if it matches the specified expression, if so it just returns the element itself. If it doesn’t match then it will continue to traverse up the document, parent by parent, until an element is found that matches the specified expression. If no matching element is found then none will be returned.
New collection which contains all interesting parents
Find all the child nodes inside the matched elements (including text nodes).
A new collection containing all child nodes of the previous collection.
Selector to filter current collection

Removes all matched elements from their parent elements, cleans up any attached events or data and clears up the Collection to free up memory.

The Collection content can be pre-filtered with an optional selector expression.

Modifies the current collection (without pushing the stack) as it removes all elements from the collection which where removed from the DOM. This normally means all elements in the collection when no selector is given.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Removes all content from the elements
The collection is returned for chaining proposes

Undone of the last modification of the collection.

These methods change the selection during a chained method call: add, children, eq, filter, find, gt, lt, next, not, parent, parents and siblings
The previous collection
The position of the element

Reduce the set of matched elements to a single element.

The position of the element in the collection of matched elements starts at 0 and goes to length – 1.
The filtered collection
An expression or function to filter
Optional context for the function to being executed in.

Removes all elements from the set of matched elements that do not match the specified expression(s) or be valid after being tested with the given function.

A selector function is invoked with three arguments: the value of the element, the index of the element, and the Array object being traversed.
The filtered collection
Selector for children to find
Searches for all elements that match the specified expression. This method is a good way to find additional descendant elements with which to process.
The found elements in a new collection
Name of the attribute
Figures out the value of the given attribute of the first element stored in the collection.
The value of the attribute
Gets the classname of the first selected element
The retrieved classname
Name of the style attribute (js variant e.g. marginTop, wordSpacing)
Choose one of the modes supported by {@link qx.bom.element2.Style#get}
Figures out the value of the given style property of the first element stored in the collection.
The value of the style property

Returns the currently configured value of the first element in the collection.

Works with simple input fields as well as with select boxes or option elements.

Returns an array in cases of multi-selection in select boxes but in all other cases a string.
The value of the first element.
The class name to check for
Whether the first selected element has the given className.
true when the element has the given classname
List of selector expressions

Insert all of the matched elements before another, specified, set of elements.

This operation is, essentially, the reverse of doing a regular qx.bom.Collection.query(A).after(B), in that instead of inserting B to A, you’re inserting A to B.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
List of selector expressions

Insert all of the matched elements after another, specified, set of elements.

This operation is, essentially, the reverse of doing a regular qx.bom.Collection.query(A).before(B), in that instead of inserting B to A, you’re inserting A to B.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Selector to check the content for
Checks the current selection against an expression and returns true, if at least one element of the selection fits the given expression.
Whether at least one element matches the given selector
Optional selector to filter the result

Get a set of elements containing the unique next siblings of each of the given set of elements.

next only returns the very next sibling for each element, not all next siblings (see {@link #nextAll}). Use an optional expression to filter the matched set.
Collection of all very next siblings of the current collection.
Optional selector to filter the result

Find all sibling elements after the current element.

Use an optional expression to filter the matched set.
Collection of all siblings following the elements of the current collection.
CSS selector expression
Removes elements matching the specified expression from the collection.
A newly created collection where the matching elements have been removed.
Optional selector to filter the result
Get a set of elements containing the unique parents of the matched set of elements.
Collection of all unique parent elements.
Optional selector to filter the result

Get a set of elements containing the unique ancestors of the matched set of elements (except for the root element).

The matched elements can be filtered with an optional expression.
Collection of all unique parent elements.
A reference to an DOM element or a HTML string

Prepend content to the inside of every matched element.

Supports lists of DOM elements or HTML strings through a variable argument list.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
List of selector expressions

Append all of the matched elements to another, specified, set of elements.

This operation is, essentially, the reverse of doing a regular qx.bom.Collection.query(A).prepend(B), in that instead of prepending B to A, you’re prepending A to B.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Optional selector to filter the result

Get a set of elements containing the unique previous siblings of each of the given set of elements.

prev only returns the very previous sibling for each element, not all previous siblings (see {@link #prevAll}). Use an optional expression to filter the matched set.
Collection of all very previous siblings of the current collection.
Optional selector to filter the result

Find all sibling elements preceding the current element.

Use an optional expression to filter the matched set.
Collection of all siblings preceding the elements of the current collection.
Selector to filter current collection

Removes all matched elements from the DOM. This does NOT remove them from the collection object, allowing you to use the matched elements further. When a selector is given the list is filtered by the selector and the chaining stack is pushed by the new collection.

The Collection content can be pre-filtered with an optional selector expression.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
The class name to remove
Removes a className from the given element
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
List of selector expressions

Replaces the elements matched by the specified selector with the matched elements.

This function is the complement to {@link #replaceWith} which does the same task with the parameters reversed.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
The class name to remove
The class name to add
Replaces the first given class name with the second one
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
A reference to an DOM element or a HTML string

Replaces all matched elements with the specified HTML or DOM elements.

This returns the JQuery element that was just replaced, which has been removed from the DOM.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Name of the attribute
Reset the given attribute on all selected elements.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Name of the attribute
New value of the attribute
Modify the given attribute on all selected elements.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Style name or Map of styles/values to apply
Style value
Modify the given style property on all selected elements.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Value to apply to each element

Applies the given value to the element.

Normally the value is given as a string/number value and applied to the field content (textfield, textarea) or used to detect whether the field is checked (checkbox, radiobutton).

Supports array values for selectboxes (multiple-selection) and checkboxes or radiobuttons (for convenience).

Please note: To modify the value attribute of a checkbox or radiobutton use {@link qx.bom.element.Attribute#set} instead.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Optional selector to filter the result

Get a set of elements containing all of the unique siblings of each of the matched set of elements.

Can be filtered with an optional expressions.
Collection of all unique sibling elements.
The class name to toggle
Toggles a className of the selected elements
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Element or HTML markup used for wrapping

Wrap each matched element with the specified HTML content.

This wrapping process is most useful for injecting additional structure into a document, without ruining the original semantic qualities of a document. This works by going through the first element provided (which is generated, on the fly, from the provided HTML) and finds the deepest descendant element within its structure—it is that element that will enwrap everything else.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Element or HTML markup used for wrapping

Wrap all the elements in the matched set into a single wrapper element.

This is different from {@link #wrap} where each element in the matched set would get wrapped with an element.

This wrapping process is most useful for injecting additional structure into a document, without ruining the original semantic qualities of a document.

This works by going through the first element provided (which is generated, on the fly, from the provided HTML) and finds the deepest descendant element within its structure—it is that element that will enwrap everything else.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
Element or HTML markup used for wrapping

Wrap the inner child contents of each matched element (including text nodes) with an HTML structure.

This wrapping process is most useful for injecting additional structure into a document, without ruining the original semantic qualities of a document. This works by going through the first element provided (which is generated, on the fly, from the provided HTML) and finds the deepest ancestor element within its structure—it is that element that will enwrap everything else.
The collection is returned for chaining proposes
